item.title: Using Putty and Emacs' Tramp on Windows
item.description: Introduction and Motivation Windows doesn't support a lot of common Unix commands, ssh included. There are several ways to overcome this fact. The Windows Subsystem for Linux is one option. I've used it and it's certainly a big step up over native windows shells. But to get any GUI applications you have to set up an X server or somesuch (to my knowledge -- which is admittedly limited at present). It's also a bit of a pain to interface natively with normal Windows files, since you have to use /mnt/c/ to get to to them.
